{"aid": "http://arxiv.org/abs/2504.10363v1", "title": "Fine-Grained Complexity via Quantum Natural Proofs", "summary": "Buhrman, Patro, and Speelman presented a framework of conjectures that
together form a quantum analogue of the strong exponential-time hypothesis and
its variants. They called it the QSETH framework. In this paper, using a notion
of quantum natural proofs (built from natural proofs introduced by Razborov and
Rudich), we show how part of the QSETH conjecture that requires properties to
be `compression oblivious' can in many cases be replaced by assuming the
existence of quantum-secure pseudorandom functions, a standard hardness
assumption. Combined with techniques from Fourier analysis of Boolean
functions, we show that properties such as PARITY and MAJORITY are compression
oblivious for certain circuit class $\Lambda$ if subexponentially secure
quantum pseudorandom functions exist in $\Lambda$, answering an open question
in [Buhrman-Patro-Speelman 2021].", "main_category": "quant-ph", "categories": "quant-ph,cs.CC", "published": "2025-04-14T16:09:55Z"}
